Management of Radiology Generated Blood Request Referrals Made Prior to Imaging……………………………………………………………………………………….7
Introduction

To provide a written procedure for radiology staff to follow in order to obtain blood results for creatinine levels for those patients in which a recent blood results is not available to review at the point of vetting the radiology request. This process should only be used in the extreme circumstances that the referring clinician has not already requested the necessary bloods.
To identify the groups of patients for which a radiology generated blood request is required.
To reduce the amount of procedures that are cancelled due to the lack of availability of blood results.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

The target audience for this policy includes the radiology administrative staff, radiographers, radiologists and the referring clinicians. This guidance should only be used for examination requests requiring IV contrast.
When required, advice should always be taken from a Senior Radiographer/Radiologist.
Only those members of radiology administrative staff trained to refer for renal profile bloods using this pathway should do so.
The clinician who referred for the examinations should be the person responsible for reviewing the bloods results on Lorenzo and acting on any findings.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)
Duties Are:
The Chief Executive
4.1.1 The Chief Executive is designated by the Trust Board as the officer with overall responsibility for Health and Safety.
4.1.2 Patient Safety Group will analyse and set the strategy for handling all aspects of clinical risk threatening patient safety within the Trust and other patient safety issues.

4.1.3 Health and Safety Group will be a proactive force in promoting the highest standards of health and safety. Any trends reported via datix pertaining to this policy will be fed back via the Therapies and Diagnostics Governance meetings.
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust  Duties Are: Referring clinician

4.2.1 It remains the referrer's responsibility to request the appropriate blood test within 4 weeks of the radiology imaging appointment and to ensure the results are available on MEHT Review or an official document is provided showing the results of the blood test. A letter or fax from a GP surgery for example.

4.2.2 The referrer must provide sufficient clinical details in order to justify the radiology examination. The referrer should also highlight whether a patient has poor renal function, hyperthyroidism or history of a previous CM reaction on the request, as these factors could prevent CM administration and in some circumstances could stop the examination from going ahead. Further to this, Oncologists should indicate if a patient is taking the Interleukin-2 drug(2) (Also known as Aldesleukin or IL-2).

4.2.3 The referrer must maintain clinical responsibility for blood tests generated by radiology on behalf of the referring clinician to ascertain the creatinine level. Results highlighted to the referrer by radiology must be acted upon appropriately. Radiology notifies the referring clinician of any abnormal results via email and takes appropriate action if an out of office is received.
Vetting Radiographer

4.2.4 The Authoriser will check the radiology request and note whether contrast is required for the examination. If contrast is required, the Authoriser will check the patients renal function results. If the patient has a eGFR result which will be within 4 weeks of the appointment, and within the required range as stated in the CT
(16031) and MR (12002) injection policies, the Authoriser will indicate to the A&C staff that the appointment can be booked.
4.2.4.1If the eGFR is not within the required range, the request will be sent to the
radiologist who will make a decision to proceed based on clinical need or discuss further with the referring clinician. The result of this decision must be recorded on the radiology system.

4.2.5 For those patients who do not have a recent eGFR result at the point of vetting, the Authoriser will add the word ‘bl00ds' to the Radiology system comment section. The word ‘bl00ds' is deliberately miss spelt so that a Radiology system stat can be pulled.

4.2.6 Assign all requests outside of their vetting scope or where a consultant's opinion is required to the radiologist for further review via the radiology system. Email the referring consultant to inform them of any abnormal blood results identified during vetting or at the three day bloods check. If an out of office appears on e-mailing the referring consultant, – an alternative member of the team must be contacted.

4.2.7 On the day of the procedure the scanning radiographer will review comments to ensure the referrer has been informed of any abnormal bloods and email the consultant if no notification has been made.
Radiologist
4.2.8 Review all requests assigned to them outside of the radiographers scope or those where the radiographers requires consultant opinion.

4.2.9 If the eGFR is not within the required range, the radiologist will make a decision to proceed based on clinical need or discuss further with the referring clinician. The result of this decision must be recorded on the radiology system.
Radiology administrative staff
4.2.10 Once a radiology referral is made, the request will be ‘clerked' and the request put on the appropriate vetting list.
4.2.11 All RADIOLOGY SYSTEM pending appointments with the word ‘bl00ds' will indicate a renal profile blood request will need to be made by radiology A&C staff.

4.2.12 Once it has been noted there was no eGFR at the point of vetting, the A&C staff will contact the patient and check no bloods have been completed since point of vetting, a blood request form is in ‘hand' or the eGFR has been completed elsewhere. If no eGFR has been done, a renal profile bloods request will be generated by the A&C staff.
Management of Radiology Generated Blood Request Referrals
Made Prior to Imaging

eGFR is the preferred way of determining kidney function than serum creatinine alone and should always be sought where possible. Guidance on the relevant timeframes and safe working levels are described in the 16031 Administration of IV Iodinated Contrast Media in Radiology and 12002 MRI Contrast Agent Administration.
Process
(Refer to Appendix 1)
5.2.1 Radiology referral made by referring clinician (NB – renal profile bloods should be requested as part of referral).
5.2.2 Referral sent to Radiology admin staff – requested ‘clarked' and put on appropriate vetting list on RADIOLOGY SYSTEM.

5.2.3 Radiographer checks all radiology requests (Even those outside of their vetting scope or those that need consultant review) and checks for recent bloods (Within 4 weeks) if contrast is likely to be required.
5.2.4 If bloods (eGFR) are available at the point of vetting – the CT and MRI contrast polices and guidelines are followed for the administration of contrast and an appointment is made.
5.2.5 If no bloods (eGFR) are available at the point of vetting, the radiographer writes ‘Bl00ds' spelt incorrectly so that the statistics can be pulled on radiology system.

5.2.6 For those patients with ‘bl00ds' written on radiology system, the radiology A&C staff contact the patient and check the patient has not had bloods done since the point of vetting/ or that a blood request form is in ‘hand' or completed elsewhere.

5.2.7 If no bloods (eGFR) have been completed, the radiology A&C staff complete bloods request for all those with ‘Bl00ds' written on radiology system, after checking with patient where their preferred hospital would be.

5.2.8 Three days prior to the appointment any outstanding blood referrals will be reviewed by the vetting radiographers. Any outstanding blood results will be highlighted to the A&C team for further investigation.

5.2.9 The referring clinician remains responsible for blood tests generated by radiology on behalf of the referring clinician to ascertain the creatinine level. They must review the bloods and act as appropriate. They must review all blood results either flagged as critical via Lorenzo or those radiology have highlighted to them and act as appropriate.
Abnormal Results

5.3.1 If abnormal results are identified by the vetting radiographer, the referring clinician will be informed via email. If an out of office is received, appropriate action will be taken by the radiographer, seeking an alternative clinician to flag the abnormal results to. A record of this will be made within the comment field on the Radiology system.

5.3.2 Patients with less than 3 days' notice of examination will not have been captured by the abnormal results procedure above. On the day of procedure, the scanning radiographers will ensure a confirmation e-mail has been sent to the referring consultant.
Training Requirements
Outline training requirements or if not appropriate state:

This policy applies to all radiology staff that refer, vet or make appointments for radiology examinations requiring contrast media to be administered. It is primarily the referrers responsibility to ensure the eGFR is available/ or requested at the point of generating a radiology request involving contrast media. Once the request is received, the Authoriser should check for an eGFR. If a recent eGFR is not available, then the pathway necessary for radiology to generate the renal profile should be followed. Please see appendix
All referrers, Authorisers and A&C staff staff should be aware of all aspects relating the Radiology Generated Blood Request Referral Pathway.
All Authorisers (radiographers/radiologists) should be able to access records of blood tests through the hospital system or the patient's GP records.
All referrers should be aware of the requirement of a current eGFR prior to contrast administration.

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Monitoring and Audit
Each document must outline the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

Assurance that the amount of bloods outstanding at the point of vetting has not increased since the introduction of this pathway
Provide current stats of the number of bloods outstandin g at the point of vetting with those after 3 months of the introductio n of this pathway.

If there is a percentage increase of more than 10% of outstanding bloods for a particular referrer, the referrer will be informed. If after the clinician is made aware and no improvement is seen this pathway will cease for that individual until the outstanding bloods (at point of vetting) reaches a level within the 10% tolerance.

data.text: Appendix 2 - Required eGFR levels prior to MRI contrast being administered
Low risk contrasts agents will only routinely be administered if the eGFR reading is above 50ml/min/1.73m², or after discussion between the referring senior clinician and the supervising radiologist.
This discussion must be documented on the radiology system prior to the scan date. Only in exceptional circumstances can gadolinium be administered to a patient with an eGFR below 30.
Medium risk contrast agents such as the liver specific MRI contrast agent
(Primovist) requires an eGFR above  If a patient referred for a Primovist liver scan has an eGFR below  then Dotarem/gadolinium can be administered instead.
A repeated dose of contrast cannot be given within 7 days unless the eGFR has been checked and is above 50ml/min/1.73m²
Those patients not requiring a blood test prior to MRI contrast administration: Any patient not in the high risk categories defined in section 3.2
MRI contrast administration contraindications
This policy does not affect the established contra indication to administering contrast agents such as asthma, allergies, hay fever etc. These should be checked as standard procedure.
